name: The Fairmont Royal York

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed May 2009, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The Fairmont Royal York is truly a beautiful old hotel. The lobby and public areas are worth a look even if you don't stay there. The location is in the financial district, directly across the street from the train station. Close to many attractions, though not much going on in the evening. Lots of restaurants as well as the underground shopping are within walking distance. As the hotel is old, the rooms are small - especially the bathroom (compared to other Fairmont hotels I've visited). A very small, old TV was the only bad part of the stay. I especially liked the seperate trash cans for recycling. The "super saver" rate was reasonable and we were very happy with our stay.
reviews.title: Beautiful Hotel

reviews.text: Just spent 7 days at the Royal York for a conference. The first day I was charmed by the old architecture and history...after that, it's just another big hotel. First disappointment was finding out I paid $229 per night and a colleague there for the same conference paid $159. Other hotels in the city were offering conference-goers 50% off food vouchers and free breakfasts, but the Fairmont offered nothing. Guess they figure they are so old, they don't need to. I had a plain room with no view at the back of the hotel overlooking an alley and office building next door. Room was small, but adequate for one person. Bed was comfortable, but the thin walls made sleeping a challenge with noisy neighbors. Bathroom was tiny and the addition of a granite countertop made sitting on the toilet a real challenge. I am a large man and was literally wedged in and couldn't move. Some hand grips in the shower would have been nice. Toiletries were nice, as others have commented, but be prepared to make the sliver of soap last 7 days as it was never replaced. The snack basket was overpriced...$4 for a small bag of M&M's! Surcharges for EVERY phone call $1.61 per local call and $23 for a 7 minute call back to the States. Free in-room coffee, but I had to request creamer from the housekeeper and she had the kitchen send some up. The free newspaper was absent one day. My perception was they were short-staffed as my room didn't get refreshed until after 6 pm one day. The hotel is convenient to downtown and connected by the underground PATH to Union Station and the subway. All in all, a nice, old property, but be prepared to pay top dollar for everything and shop around for the best rates, as they apparently vary widely.
reviews.title: Feel cheated...

reviews.text: We (a small group attending an event in town) booked four rooms for one night: one king and three doubles. Fairmont was offering a tremendous rate for the night as part of its "Be an Original" campaign ($109 Canadian), which made the Royal York less expensive than many inferior properties in the vicinity. Since we were arriving by train, we loved the idea of the hotel's attachment to Union Station via an underground walkway- what a great way to arrive!
reviews.title: One of the Great Big-City Historic Hotels

reviews.text: I love the big-city vibe this hotel gives off: lots of people milling about, ballrooms hosting elegant functions, lounges filled with business people enjoying an after-work cocktail, lots of little shops to browse among down below in the concourse. The staff is well trained, very professional and pleasant. I enjoyed cocktails in the library lounge listening to an excellent guitarist play a variety of tunes.
reviews.title: Fabulous experience at the Royal York

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed May 2009, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We were assigned rooms on the 6th floor. The three doubles were in the West Wing of the building, and my king was in the East Wing. My king room had obviously been more recently redecorated than the doubles-- more modern furnishings, more neutral decor, flat screen television. The three doubles still have decor from the late '80's (rose carpet, lots of chintz fabric and floral wallpaper) but all of the elements were well-maintained.
reviews.title: Elegant, Classy, perfectly located city hotel with 1920's charm thrown in.
Lovely Old Hotel
reviews.text: Yes it is an old hotel, but in a town of concrete and glass it has a stately charm seldom found. Our first room had no safe but the bellboy immediately had us transferred before our suitcases were unloaded, the room was of a good size and clean although there was a big hole where the minibar should be. However this is part of the Hotel's upgrading which also includes a lot of exterior work but this did not cause any hindrance The staff were lovely apart from the Concierge who had to be prompted to take our details when my wife lost a lovely hat. All in all would thoroughly recommend the hotel for it's old world charm, staff and situation which was excellent.

reviews.title: Beautiful landmark hotel
reviews.text: Such a beautiful grand old hotel! The location is perfect, right downtown Toronto. The rooms are a good size and well appointed. It is impressive inside, the decorations, the furniture are so beautiful, if you like opulent, old world charm; chandeliers, marble, velvet curtains this is it, but definitely not for peole who like modern, edgy, zen look! The staff is extremely nice and helpful.

reviews.title: Stunning building but rooms in need of some TLC
reviews.text: There's a little bit of construction going on in the area and the hotel is doing some renovations as well, but it didn't bother us at all except for the gym that was closed, but the hotel made arrangements with other facilities close by. The food was very good at the library bar. Nice little shops downstairs.

reviews.title: Old world charm, maybe time to update
reviews.text: They simply don't build them like this anymore!

reviews.title: Royal sparkle
reviews.text: This hotel is in a great location. The building itself is gorgeous and the lobby, restaurants and bars are stunning.
This hotel is located in the heart of downtown Toronto. It is beautiful inside and out, and has great service. You feel like a king/queen with the beautiful decorations and attentive service.
reviews.title: Beautiful, central hotel!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2009, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The hotel is steps from everything downtown you could want: subway, CN Tower, Rogers Centre, Skydome, Opera house, eaton centre, union station, st. lawrence market and more!
reviews.title: Historic Hotel, requires a little money spent.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed June 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The hotel is expensive, but not that much more than other, less nice, hotels in Toronto.
reviews.title: Elegant Hotel Wonderful Location

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We stayed here for 2 nights & very much enjoyed our suite on the 14th floor, this hotel was built by Canadian Pacific Railway in 1929 for passengers for the Union Station,. The hotel is located above PATH, a vast underground shopping and transportation complex with access to Union Station and the CN Tower is three blocks away, so the location is great in every way. The Hotel was built in huge blocks, it has 1300 rooms, oftern these blocks look into the back of buildings or into each other, so beware! We found the Hotel Lobby to be glorious & the Conference & Banqueting rooms to be as sumptious as the Palace of Versailles, absolutely wonderful!
reviews.title: Always a lovely getaway

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed December 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: However the Hotel is, in some areas, in need of a refurb, especially the older rooms on the middle floors. Breakfast is a good Buffet with efficient staff, but again you could be one of the 3000 guests. Also there is a huge conference business, due to the sheer size & number of the conference rooms there. The leisure centre is small but good. We would recommend, go enjoy the history and look at the pics on the Balcony- fascinating!
reviews.title: Suite Romantic Weekend!
aging hotel with a great location and views
reviews.text: My partner and I stayed at the Royal York Fairmont for two nights over New Year's, and overall I would say that the service is very personable and welcoming, but the hotel is obviously aged quite a bit.

reviews.title: Fantastic Service In A Grand Setting
reviews.text: Being part of the President's Club in Fairmont, we were upgraded to a two-bedroom suite. The room itself was enormous, and for whatever reason we had a second bedroom. As shown in the pictures, we had a dining room table and a china cabinet and a sitting room. This seemed like a suite more for corporate entertaining, since there was a mini kitchenettes with a bar. The views were absolutely amazing, and we could see the CN Tower right from our bed.

reviews.title: Just Average
reviews.text: Check-in was easy, and the service throughout the hotel was good, suffice for some small issues. The location of the film is in the financial center, and originally, I didn't know if that was going to be good or bad, because being downtown in some cities at night or on the weekend is a recipe for abandoned streets and closed stores. But the Royal York's location at the Union Station subway made it accessible all night with people walking around. I can't say I had a problem with the hotel's location, especially considering our amazing views.

reviews.title: Well situated for a quick meeting in Toronto Financial District
reviews.text: But I will say that the Royal York is showing its wear after all these years. I know the hotel is historic and notable, but it's clear there hasn't been much renovation when I walk around the main hallways and the room. I heard that half of the hotel is going through major renovation, so I'm sure this aspect of my review would not be relevant once that is completed, but I certainly agree that a renovation is needed.

reviews.title: Could be better
reviews.text: I also think that the housekeeping and room service aspects could use some work. I understand that the suite is a large area to clean, but the state of our shower -- in particular -- was extremely ridiculous. There was soap left from the previous guest, and the showerhead was disgusting and looked as if it hadn't been cleaned for a year. I felt like that guy from the TV show "Hotel Impossible" when he gets grossed out with the state of the rooms...that's how I felt with this showerhead. I took a picture of it to illustrate what I was talking about. Also, our coffee machine in the room did not work the first morning, and so we told the concierge who said that it would be fixed or replaced, and then later in the day he said it was replaced. So the next morning, we try to use the coffee machine and it didn't work and we're standing there trying to figure out how this didn't work until we embarrassingly call room service to say that we can't figure out how to work the coffee machine, and then they said they never replaced it in the first place. So we said we would like some coffee from room service since the machine was broken from yesterday, and it literally never came for the three hours before we had to check out. That's a complete breakdown in their communication and service, and left a bad taste in our mouth as we were leaving.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2009, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: I have always wanted to stay in one of the Fairmont historic railroad hotels, so I jumped at the chance to stay at the Royal York during a recent trip to Toronto. It was lovely and conveniently located. It was nice to be so close to Union Station and the skyway to the CN Tower, especially because it rained quite a bit while we were there. There were some nice little shops on the basement level of the hotel.
reviews.title: Very nice

reviews.text: It's obvious that the hotel is older, and certain things are to be expected (we had toilet flushing problems). However, the historic nature of the place makes it worthwhile, in my opinion. Really enjoyed our stay and would recommend to others.
reviews.title: Wonderful reception areas, tired rooms in this very Grand hotel

reviews.text: The reception areas in this hotel are breathtaking. The location is very good, right opposite Toronto's main railway station. The staff is excellent. The rooms, however are tired and mine had such a poor outlook over a roof to another wing of the hotel that I had to keep my curtains closed the whole time to prevent being looked in on.
reviews.title: Great Hotel

likes.disliked: — Wrong charges on account of mini bar usage

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed March 2009, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: As often, in old historic buildings, it is a huge challenge to adapt the building into a modern hotel. The rooms are often all different and so you can be lucky and find yourself in a huge light room or unlucky and end up in a small dingy room with no outlook. There was nothing wrong or broken with the bathroom or general furnishings, just the size of the room and overall feel of the room which is no fault of the hotel owners but the building itself.
reviews.title: Horrible - Needs to be closed and retrofitted

reviews.text: As long as you stay out of your room the rest of the hotel is magnificent.
reviews.title: A grand old hotel
Return visit...will likely return again...
reviews.text: I spent New Year's 2012/2013 with friends in Toronto and chose the Royal York again. I was booked into the same style single King Bed NS suite in which I stayed a couple of years ago and was pleasantly suprised to see some overall improvements in the room and hotel since my last stay. The curbside staff were very helpful and checked my baggage upon exiting my taxi. The front desk staff were very courteous and helpful at check-in and my bags were in my room by the time I returned from a short walk to the store. The room itself appeared brighter and more updated since my last stay. The bathroom, though not large, was thoroughly adequate and the addition of a glass shelf above the sink/counter was a helpful touch. Like many older hotels there was no bathroom fan, however. There was not a full thermostat in the room, just settings for cool/hot and hi/med/low fan speeds but it seemed perfectly adequate for climate control. Decent mini-bar and snacks, but no Splenda or natural Stevia sweetner for coffee - only the dubious aspartame or cyclamate sweetners. Although every hotel with Lodgenet or similar entertainment options doesn't go out of their way to provide a full selection of basic cable channels, the selection at the Royal York wasn't bad - although I don't understand why they didn't have the cooking channel or food channel as these might likely increase traffic at the onsite restaurants and/or room service:) The hotel connects to the underground PATH walkway that connects most of the major downtown building and shopping centres, but be warned that the financial district in which the Royal York is situated is pretty dead on the weekends. Also, getting through Union Station and finding your way back onto the PATH system is rather confusing - even the polite lady Transit Officer I asked for directions could not clearly indicate how to get through Union Station. Nonetheless, the hotel has some great amenities nearby - 2 blocks over you will find a Longo's megastore complex that includes a boutique wine store, an LCBO, a wine tasting bar, and a Starbucks. If you're looking for organic, though, be advised that although Longo's is akin to Whole Foods, the organic selection of fresh produce is limited to a rather small section along a back wall - ask for specifics when you get there. The Royal York fitness facilities are pretty decent with a good sized pool and good selection of cardio and weights. The Concierge was very helpful and the Business Centre is well-equipped with helpful staff, but don't expect late night hours as noted by another reviewer. That being said, I had an early morning (4AM) check-out and the front desk and curbside were both well staffed and very helpful. I'm returning to Toronto in May and will likely stay at the Royal York again.

reviews.title: Good for business travel
reviews.text: I stay at The Fairmont every time I travel to Toronto (about twice per year) and I enjoy it traditional and stoic surroundings. Staff is very friendly and helpful and available. The LIbrary bar is good for munchies and a cold Canadian beer or cocktail. Breakfast is high end and very good. Internet service is fast, and the rooms are well appointed and insulated. I hear nothing when I am in my room sleeping or working. Location is great with access to the underground (and lots of shopping) and walking distance from all of the downtown businesses.

reviews.title: If you need to work late, stay elsewhere
reviews.text: I booked the hotel because I thought it would be a good place to get work done, right in the financial center and it advertised a business center. I checked-in to dopr my bags in my room, went to dinner and came back to start work. That's when I was told the business center is closed, I asked for the concierge so I could arrange some color printing and computer access at maybe a Kinkos - I was told the concierge is closed and the front desk wasn't aware of anything nearby.

reviews.title: not impressed
reviews.text: So after I ended up checking out immediately (total 4 hour stay) and flew back early to finish work... I asked for a refund or voucher towards my next stay. The room was UNUSED (had only dropped off my bags in it), Fairmont president club member and the hotel was NOT sold out.. Got nothing at all.

reviews.title: nice enough stay
reviews.text: I wasn't impressed at all with this hotel. Arriving at about 2am, I was put into a stagnant rooms miles from the elevator - to find what appeared to be a wall against the window. It was actually scaffolding with protective covering -but was not aware/wasn't told. I then returned to the desk and asked for a different room and had to wait twenty minutes for the gentleman to find an appropriate place. The room offered was again stagnant - but also smelled of cigarettes. I really wasn't impressed and followed up with the hotel management who looked after me. I was surprised with this being a Fairmont Hotel the level of service and quality of accommodation. Best avoided.

I agree with most of the other reviewers about the hotel. The building itself is nice and has that historic feel (especially the lobby), but the rooms need some TLC. I undestand they are beginning to renovate the rooms, but I was not lucky enough to get one that was updated. My room (especially the bathroom) was very small, there was some wallpaper peeling from the walls and the furniture showed its age. On the other hand, the room was clean, the bed was comfortable and housekeeping was responsive when I asked for foam pillows. For some reason, I could not access the free WiFi (after calling for assistance) and finding an outlet to plug my phone charger into was nearly impossible. I worked out at the health club and the facility itself was average compared to other hotel gyms. I forgot to bring a pair of socks and was quite pleased that the gym attendant was able to get me some at no charge. I haven't stayed at a Fairmont before, so I really don't have a strong opinion about the brand, however I guess I expected a little more refinement.
reviews.title: What I expected, I guess.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2012, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: I've reviewed The Royal York before and wanted to add that after yet another visit we experiencesd another exceptional high level of customer service.
reviews.title: Still a great hotel

reviews.text: On this occasion the Front Desk staff were exceptional and anticipated needs before we even realised them ourselves. When we arrived the guy at reception noticed we'd been allocated a room where the outdoor scaffolding was and advised that as we were staying a full week he wanted us to have a room without this obstructing our view. None was available but he offered us $25 drinks vouchers whilst we waited and offered to call us back when ready. He called within 10 mintutes and we still had the vouchers.
reviews.title: Best trip ever!

reviews.text: Again we enjoyed our stay at the hotel and will keep returning. For more detailed reviews of the hotel please see our past review of the Royal York.
reviews.title: Looking a bit tired

reviews.text: Now I travel a lot and stay in a lot of hotels, some fantastic, some not, some real new and some real old and no matter what every time I stay at the Fairmont Royal York I get the royal treatment. Not always from a room upgrade, although that is truly what I received this time, but also the service and the lovely staff they have working at this property. The Sales Manager, Robin Sheikh, is one of the best pieces of the property (he's been there 15 years so he definitely is part of the furniture); if you are ever in Toronto for business or organizing a conference or some other event make sure you give the Fairmont Royal York a call, you will be surprised by your royal treatment. And remember to have a macaroon!!
reviews.title: Beginning to Show Her Age

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed June 2009, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Stayed 4 nights late June, early July in a gold club room with a king bed. The rooms are small for club level, but overall very nice. We were able to walk to everything we wanted to see, although it was a long walk to Royal Ontario Museum, Yorkville, etc. Staff was pleasant and helpful. Plenty of nice restaurants within a 10-15 minute walk. Dhaba on King St has the best Indian food I have ever eaten. I hope to get back to Toronto but next time will probably stay in a hotel 6-8 blocks north as our interests revolve more around museums, etc than CN Tower, entertainment district, etc. Great city and very easy to navigate (and I get lost EVERYWHERE).
reviews.title: Nice for 1st Visit to Toronto

reviews.text: I've been traveling to downtown Toronto from NYC since I was 14 (and that was a verry long time ago!) I've stayed in many places from a summer dorm room rental on a local college campus to a few 4-star hotels
reviews.title: Dear old money hotel

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed June 2009, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: I'd always felt the Royal York was out of reach for me, price-wise (I look at it as the Waldorf-Astoria of Toronto- very lush, plush, very "Old Money"). But for this weekend getaway, they actually had the best hotel rates (if paid in advance via their website: $86.00 pp+tax, USD). Surprisingly, for this rate I had a rather large, comfortable room overlooking the front of the hotel, with all the fancy hotel amenities.
reviews.title: Wonderful Hotel....

reviews.text: It is a very grand hotel, lots of brocade upholstery, marble in the lobby, and wood paneling. The staff couldn't have been nicer. Very convenient location too- close to the harbor, railway station (across the street). The health club/pool also nice .
reviews.title: Amazing

reviews.text: The downside: Though the bathrooms were renovated, much of the furniture (in my room, as well as the lobby bar) was thread-bare and worn down. The king size bed was also old and a little too hard for my back. Hotel food is usually overly expensive and this was no exception, even with the USD/CAD exchange rate.
reviews.title: Great stay in historic landmark!

aka: The Fairmont Royal York Hotel Toronto
